subject: 60 Minutes E-mail Alert
body:
CBSNews.com












  Home | U.S. | World | Politics | SciTech | Health | Entertainment | Business | Opinion | Sports | Blogs | Interactives | Video 

  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday Morning | Face The Nation 






Who is Mitt Romney 
      and what does he stand for? The Republican presidential candidate sits 
      down with Mike Wallace in our 
      lead piece to explain his political positions – some of which have changed 
      over the years – and to talk about his Mormon religion, which he thinks 
      few voters really understand. You’ll meet a man who, despite being a 
      dark horse, is convinced he can make a good president based on his success 
      in business, re-tooling ailing companies into profitable ones, his 
      budget-balancing record as governor of Massachusetts, and 
      his timely rescue of the 2002 Olympics from financial ruin. You’ll also 
      meet the entire Romney family at their lake house in New Hampshire, one 
      of the few states where he leads in the polls. If he can win that 
      state and two more early primary states like Iowa and South 
      Carolina, Romney says he’s halfway to Washington. "Look, 
      if I do well in those first three and get the momentum from those wins, 
      why that carries me to the nomination of my party."
 
Watch an excerpt of Wallace's 
      interview.
 
You’ve been hearing for months 
      about how weak the housing market is, with so much inventory and not 
      enough demand. It’s enough already to drive a real estate sales person 
      crazy, but it may be getting even worse for the traditional realtor. Lesley Stahl discovers in our 
      second report that the six percent sales commission that has been the 
      mainstay for realtors for decades could be in trouble, too.  Now 
      under pressure from Internet discounters, realtors may have to accept 
      lower commissions more regularly, as cyber dealers move onto their sacred 
      turf and charge less.
 
Our third segment is about an 
      incredible young man whose luck and determination have allowed him to rise 
      above what for most would be a horrible fate. Ali Abbas lost most of 
      his family and both his arms to a stray American bomb in Iraq four years ago. But 
      thanks to many well wishers who learned about him through the news, he is 
      adjusting, even thriving in England. Bob Simon meets a boy whose 
      writing and drawing talents would be remarkable in a person who could use 
      his hands. The talented Ali does both with his feet.  
      
 
These stories and Andy Rooney 
      reeling in the years, this Sunday, May 13, on 60 Minutes at 7 p.m. 
      ET/PT.
